Award.AwardTitle: HCC: Small: Collaborative Research: The Influence of Self-Avatars on Perception and Action in Virtual Worlds

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this research is to enable more effective design and use of virtual worlds. The pervasiveness of visually-oriented online and interactive digital media allows people to represent themselves increasingly through surrogates in virtual worlds. These digital personae are called "avatars," and when they closely represent the user, "self-avatars." Self-avatars enable forms of learning, interaction, and skill development that can increase a user's effectiveness in a virtual world. This project will explore how self-avatars play a significant role through three key components of perception and action: the relationship between action and the perception of space and objects, active acquisition of spatial memory, and the planning and execution of actions themselves.

This research will consider three properties of self-avatars themselves, each likely to have an effect across a broad range of situations: (1) the virtual perspective from which the avatar is seen, (2) the nature of the coupling between user size and motion and avatar size and motion, and (3) the naturalness of the interface system by which the user controls the avatar. The work builds on a growing body of knowledge about the role of body ownership in perceptual and cognitive tasks. This framework provides a theory in which to ground the research, a body of empirical knowledge about perception and action in the real world, and established methodologies that can be used for assessing the results of the research. The ability to utilize work from cognitive and perceptual science to solve a problem in computer graphics and user interaction is a major strength of the research.

Virtual environments are important in many domains, including architecture, education, medicine, simulation, training, and visualization. The core impact of this research is to enable self-avatars to enhance user experience in virtual environments, which are a major category of computer simulations. A broad impact of this project is that enhancing the user experience will lead to more capable applications of virtual environments in the aforementioned domains. This research will also have utility in entertainment systems, the dominant environments for avatars. It advances discovery and understanding while training students in cross-disciplinary research methods in an innovative intellectual environment. The interdisciplinary nature of the research and its consequent applications, together with the close integration of two research groups, will aid in bringing new students to computer science, beyond the students traditionally attracted to that field.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Virtual environments are three-dimensional graphical experiences of places or things that you see as if you were inside a video game. There are entertainment and news applications of virtual environments, like 3D video games, or surround stories that appear in the New York Times and can be viewed through a smartphone and a Google cardboard. There are also applications of virtual environments where people learn and train, usually in situations where it is too difficult or too expensive to learn or train in the real world. Usually, when people view or are "inside" these virtual environments, they do not see themselves, or any moving representation of themselves. They just see themselves surrounded by images of an environment that is virtual, but if, for example, they look down, they don't see their feet.

With some extra equipment, it is possible to put a graphical character or representation in a virtual environment that tracks a person's movements. When this is done, the graphical character is called a self-avatar. Since it requires extra hardware and software to do this well, the purpose of this research was to explore what a self-avatar was good for. Some things about a self-avatar were known and were clear. It is reasonably clear that if you want to operate in a virtual environment with more than one person, that is, have social interactions, then having the other people be able to see one's self is important. Our work was not focused on social interactions, but rather on understanding if, how and why a self-avatar helped people act and perceive in a virtual environment on their own.

We found that in general, a self-avatar provides important information about the nature of what is possible or not possible in a virtual environment. Possibilities for action in an environment, not just a virtual one, are called the affordances of the environment, and they are important in the design of virtual environments and computer interfaces. Our results provide a way to measure how closely a virtual environment matches the real world by looking at how closely the affordances track those in the real world. We showed that with a self-avatar, the affordances can track so closely as to be indistinguishable. We looked at whether the form of the self-avatar was important in making these affordance judgments; that is, is the graphical model's appearance important making affordance judgments that are close to in the real world. We found that the form of the graphical model does not seem to be important. We showed that we could change the size of the self-avatar (scale it) and a person's perceptions of what they were able to do in the virtual environment scaled with it, and tracked differently to what they were capable of in the real world.

We also looked at how well modern virtual reality equipment performs in such tasks when compared to equipment that costs orders of magnitude more, and found that it performs as well or better in most circumstances. And we looked at the illusion of self-motion in virtual environments, called vection. This is the feeling that you get when you are sitting in a car and the car next to you starts to move and for an instant you feel like you are moving. This feeling can be induced by visual stimuli, and we examined how and why it can happen in virtual environments.

In conclusion, virtual environments provide people with opportunities to experience places and situations remote from their actual physical surroundings. Virtual environments could have a huge impact in education and other fields but they are not widely used because of their expense and delicacy. We have shown that animated self-avatars, the digital representation of the user in graphical form, is a critical component of virtual environments if fidelity for purposes of perception and action is to be achieve. As part of our outreach, we demonstrated these virtual environments to K-12 students interested in science and technology.
